results.content:
I'm only in section 2: Typescript Fundamentals, and it is obvious the instructor has a local dev environment tailored to work with angular and typescript. This is never adequately explained to the user, and so I had a lot of difficulty just getting the same code samples working.

I have nine years of experience with JavaScript and several years operating it from the command line, and have developed educational content around setting up cross platform development environments and working with specific software stacks. That said, there is a lot of friction getting up and running with Typescript in of itself that this section does not adequately cover.

I'll preface this next part that I use Sublime Text. So I'm not sure if VS Code is doing some behind the scenes work to improve the experience because I had to do the following to get any of the code samples to work.

- Add a missing tsconfig.json file
- Use `tsc -p .` because `tsc main.ts` won't use the tsconfig.json manifest by default
- Configure the tsconfig.json lib compiler option to use the es2017 and dom libraries in order for basic javascript features to function (eg: console...)

I've spent a fair bit of time googling these issues just to get the environment setup so that I can work through the examples, and by this point, I would assume anyone just getting started would have abandoned this section due to how many problems are encountered.

I don't think prescribing a code editor is the right fix because most devs already have a preferred editor or environment. But not explaining these apparently crucial components and an obvious lack of play testing the video content with other devs prior to releasing this series has lead to a number of missteps that I think really hurt the onboarding experience for new devs wanting to get into this ecosystem.

All this to say, I finally have a working environment to continue this series with, and I hope this feedback will help to make this series even better.

results.content:
The course is not up to date. The version of Angular used is too old and a lot of modules are deprecated now. It is understandable that updating the entire course at this point is quite difficult, but at the very least, the teaching assistant should answer the questions to help us code in newer versions of Angular. 
I never found any useful answer from the teaching assistant. I always had to search on google, read the Angular documentation and refer multiple blogs to solve the errors. The teaching assistant hardly answers any question properly. The only help you can get are the replies of other students on the questions posted. Other than that, you get absolutely no help from the teaching assistant.
Even though the instructor Mosh is good, this course is not worth because you won't get any help if you are stuck.

The instructor makes the lessons very easy to follow along in the beginning. As soon as you get ab it further into the course, you run into a few problems. The lessons do not follow what you have in your code that you have been following along. The videos are outdated so you end up having to spend a lot more time trying to figure out why it doesn't work.

UPDATE: I am about 25% through the course and the videos are really outdated. This is slowing down progress a lot. On the one hand, it allows me to debug and search for the answer but I am not learning this as fast as I can. The Q&A are mostly old and some are not relevant.

results.content:
So far, it seems that the course is structured in a way that allows a developer with a basic knowledge to learn without problems.
Sadly, there are a few differences between the foundations of a newly set up Angular app of the course and my own.
That is likely due to different versions.
Furthermore, ".endsWith()" throws a compiling error because it is not compatible with ES5 which is the most cross-browser compatible version of JS.
However, even if the fact that the course is using an older version is not ideal for a beginner, that helps with learning different Angular versions and how to upgrade to newer ones.

results.content:
I have installed Angular 11 on my machine, but the major parts of the course are on previous versions, so there is a drastic change in almost all the sessions, except the first 3-4 ones. For each of those lectures I needed to google to see how I can do the same things in the lecture in the new Angular version. That would take a hell lots of the time so I would recommend the course for others!

Another problem is that each video in each lecture is not in the continuation of the previous videos and starts with a new project! It should be more continuous!

results.content:
Mosh is a fantastic teacher! He doesn't babble which I find a lot of instructors do. He knows the point he wants to make and he makes it. No more, no less. His teaching style is similar to his approach to coding in that he always chooses the shortest and cleanest syntax. All the concepts are in order too, you get taught the things you need to know as you need to know them. 

I've tried other courses that have the, "do this, do that" approach, with no explanation as to why or what the building blocks actually are as you interact with them.

I was so pleasantly surprised in how he teaches Angular by making sure you have a firm understanding of Typescript and how it relates to Javascript and Angular development. I had some basic Javascript coding ability before this course but this course really helped me fill in some gaps and understand where, when and why to write certain things.

Mosh, you did a fantastic job with this course. Its so well written, laid out, and delivered. I will buy anything you create from here on out. Probably the best course I've ever taken.

results.content:
Crash course is just like getting some basic experience for free. Deliberate changes that make app not working as an effect of minor refactorings + clear explanation why things happened. I love it!

Now one thing I really miss is a decent review that would actually make us apply the newly learnt techniques. About 30% of the material gets covered in these (i'm at lecture 73), and I understand it's because shooting a video of these takes time.
My vote would be for old-style exercises in a form of plain-text assignments - and about 30 times more of them.

Wrapping up, this is a really great course, but it leaves coming up with repetition tasks to the student, meaning you can't exactly review your problems with other students here.

I've switched to a different course which explains the basics more extensively. I will get back to this course when I have a deeper understanding of the basics.

results.content:
There was way too much time spent on error handling. Most of the information in the http course could have been cut in half. The app was restructured at least two times during this part of the course as the teacher goes into too much depth about how to implement error handling that is redundant and doesn't apply to the final structure of the app. Unfortunately, this takes a lot of time and prevents you from moving on to other important information about Angular. If you buy this course be sure to be prepared to spend a lot of time on error handling, including doing research on your own to understand everything that's going on.

Also, there's no lesson on how to use Input decorators with router-outlet. There only a simple lesson on how to use those decorators before even getting to the routes lesson. This can be a big issue if you're planning on building an app with RouterModule.

That being said, the teacher is knowledgeable about Angular and the in the other sections of the course, he gets to the point quickly and gives examples that you can easily understand.

results.content:
Up to the firebase demo, everything was excellent.  Videos were informative and programming exercises were good.

With firebase demo, there is backwards compatibility problem and so information in the videos is now wrong.  Some of it you can find some answers by googling.  But it is a real challenge and seems distracting to the main goals of the course.     Looking at the forum, it seems that many are asking similar questions but no answers are provided.

After firebase demo, I didn't encounter compatibility problems until the sections on unit and integration testing.   For these, I gave up on the attached materials and just created my own projects to learn about the testing features.

All in all, a very good course but be prepared for some challenges with Angular version incompatibilities.

response.content: Kim, thank you for your feedback. Believe it or not, in the videos I'm typing at half the speed as I normally do just to make sure people can follow along! It's hard to go slower than that because it may bore other students who don't want to sit there and wait for me to type! You may find it more practical to watch each video with full attention first, then try to remember and type on your own. Since videos are short, you should be able to do that and this will have better impact on your learning. Good luck!

results.content:
Honestly it's not a bad course for the price, but there are numerous times throughout the course especially as you get further into it, where the level of explanation for certain aspects is lacking, which is frustrating when you actually want to learn how these things work from start to end (which is something you will need if you want to get good at developing). 

Despite this the course does offer a very wide breadth of information and topics which will provide you with a fairly comprehensive understanding of typescript, more around the syntax of things rather than the inner workings. 

One note is that there are aspects which are outdated, causing some confusion when trying to write Moshes code and it doesn't work as expected(This is something you will likely encounter with most courses but worth a mention)

Final conclusion is that for the money whatever price it's on sale on at the time, it's worth it for someone who is totally new to Angular 2+/Typescript.

results.content:
Second Stage review (4 stars)
-----------------------------
Lot of content related to Firebase and Angular Material are now out dated as the latest versions need to be coded slightly differently. This makes learning longer and difficult as you have to refer back and forth between the tutorial, online documentation and Q&A sections.  Animations section was very boring and difficult to follow through.

Initial Review (5 stars)
------------------
I like the part where the instructor explains the whys. He teaches you the difficult way of doing something and then tells you easier way so you can really appreciate Angular as you learn it throughout the course.

results.content:
Excellent course. I have now completed several Udemy courses and can authoritatively say that this is one of the best. 

Mosh is a great teacher, and that is the huge difference maker. Most other courses have teachers with skills but not the pedagogical mindset. Here, each section lays out a singular concept or group of concepts, starts with an easy to understand simple implementation, and then builds. 

In addition, you cover stumbling blocks, alternatives, limitations of implementation strategies, and find better ways to achieve the same goal. Mosh discusses trade-offs between implementations as well.

Finally, the exercises and project at the end are top notch and totally worth the price of admission on their own. This is a good one. Enjoy :)

results.content:
My rating is based on the class code being current as of today.  Everything Mosh shows me on the screen I can duplicate on my computer without any environment errors.  I don't have to dig through Google to find out why my commands don't work the same as his does in the class. It just works.  
Mosh takes the time to explain the important things, and doesn't spend time on the advanced stuff, i.e. "We'll get to that later"  Is nice as I know it's an advanced feature that I need to be aware of, but I don't have to learn it now.  Over all I'm very happy with this course.

results.content:
Very thorough sections covering the different aspects of Angular. The assignments cover what you have learned in the last section, and require you to take an extra step to complete. Some are challenging, but it is worth the time taken to complete them.

The problem is that the section about firebase is outdated and uses deprecated functions. Therefore, you will have to learn this yourself.

Overall, the angular and front-end related topics are well reviewed, but if you want to go deep into the back-end, this course will not deliver your expectations.

results.content:
The course is great, all explanations are clear and precise.

The only thing that bugs me is the fact that many code examples are not as verbose as they should  be. Many declarations are contracted, I saw if-statements with only one subordinated instruction without curly brackets. I consider this a bad practice and definitely not a good example for beginner programmers. These will lead to countless hours of unclear debugging. :) Sometimes code that's a little more verbose makes a huge difference in maintainability.

results.content:
I recommend this course without any reservations.

I want to thank Mosh for making available this revamped Angular 4 course at no additional cost to those of us who bought the original Angular 2 course.  I had given up on that course because the numerous changes that were happening in the Angular 2 beta which made it difficult for a novice to follow.  I was glad to see that I could pick the course back up when the dust settled around Angular 4.  Thank you!

This is a much improved, well thought out course.  Mosh's teaching techniques have reached a new level of clarity and effectiveness.

Two aside comments - I would like to see the subject of SEO as related to Angular and SPA covered because I have not yet found a complete treatment of this subject.  Also, I have been able to perform these assignments on a Windows 10 WSL environment using the Linux versions of node, npm and git while having my code project directories in the Windows file system and using the Windows version of Visual Studio Code - a very nice combination.

response.content: Hi Danny, glad to see you're back and are enjoying my brand new Angular course. It took a while to create this second edition and I want to thank you for your patience. I'll put your suggestion about SEO in my list and see if I can add some useful content to the course. Thanks for taking your time to leave a review and I wish you all the best!
response.content_html: Hi Danny, glad to see you're back and are enjoying my brand new Angular course. It took a while to create this second edition and I want to thank you for your patience. I'll put your suggestion about SEO in my list and see if I can add some useful content to the course. Thanks for taking your time to leave a review and I wish you all the best!

results.content_html:
I recommend this course without any reservations.

I want to thank Mosh for making available this revamped Angular 4 course at no additional cost to those of us who bought the original Angular 2 course. I had given up on that course because the numerous changes that were happening in the Angular 2 beta which made it difficult for a novice to follow. I was glad to see that I could pick the course back up when the dust settled around Angular 4. Thank you!

This is a much improved, well thought out course. Mosh's teaching techniques have reached a new level of clarity and effectiveness.

Two aside comments - I would like to see the subject of SEO as related to Angular and SPA covered because I have not yet found a complete treatment of this subject. Also, I have been able to perform these assignments on a Windows 10 WSL environment using the Linux versions of node, npm and git while having my code project directories in the Windows file system and using the Windows version of Visual Studio Code - a very nice combination.

results.content: Was badgered to improve initial 4.5 rating by instructor’s assistant in direct message.  I reported this and have to wonder if the ratings here are inflated.  That aside, this course is not for anyone who wants to get up to speed on the new angular in any reasonable timeframe.  It is extremely slow and should probably be one-third its present length.  There are no good, PRACTICAL examples, only one project and the subjects offered are not covered in any way that is conducive to real-world coding.  For example, event handling section has a series of console logs, one key-up and that’s it (maybe, unless I was too bored to follow adequately).  The instructor claims in this section that passing parameters is not ok in OOP, and this is incorrect.  Encapsulation requires the passing of parameters, period!  The section on forms is much more confusing than it needs to be, and when using the pattern attribute, he puts in a string literal rather than a real regex.  Make some forms starting simple and then add more complexity!  Reactive forms lectures much better, but the example of checking for unique value for username is USELESS. In general I find myself going through these long-winded lectures with very little substance that will help me do what I do better – create full stack applications with angular and other tools.  He does know angular concepts well and the class is organized well.  The project, while missing a practical component (billing api), is pretty well-done.
results.content_html: Was badgered to improve initial 4.5 rating by instructor’s assistant in direct message. I reported this and have to wonder if the ratings here are inflated. That aside, this course is not for anyone who wants to get up to speed on the new angular in any reasonable timeframe. It is extremely slow and should probably be one-third its present length. There are no good, PRACTICAL examples, only one project and the subjects offered are not covered in any way that is conducive to real-world coding. For example, event handling section has a series of console logs, one key-up and that’s it (maybe, unless I was too bored to follow adequately). The instructor claims in this section that passing parameters is not ok in OOP, and this is incorrect. Encapsulation requires the passing of parameters, period! The section on forms is much more confusing than it needs to be, and when using the pattern attribute, he puts in a string literal rather than a real regex. Make some forms starting simple and then add more complexity! Reactive forms lectures much better, but the example of checking for unique value for username is USELESS. In general I find myself going through these long-winded lectures with very little substance that will help me do what I do better – create full stack applications with angular and other tools. He does know angular concepts well and the class is organized well. The project, while missing a practical component (billing api), is pretty well-done.

results.content:
Having purchased over a dozen courses or subscriptions to learning sites throughout much of this year in an attempt to truly learn and internalize Angular, I've come across many courses that are comprehensive in their coverage of Angular topics and taught by friendly, well-intentioned instructors that clearly understand what they're teaching.  However, at least as of today, you will not find one as effective as this one, particularly at the beginner to intermediate level.

Mosh combines thoughtful and detailed explanations, clean and effective visual aids, and a relaxed demeanor throughout the course to disarm one seemingly scary concept after another and impart clarity and confidence.  Even if you already have access to other courses on Angular, this one is guaranteed to fill in the gaps in your understanding of the framework/platform, and further strengthen concepts you may already have begun using (if tentatively).

Also, Mosh just recently added several new sections covering the development of a comprehensive Angular + Firebase app from scratch, in which he talks you through each step of the process and demonstrates coding best practices.  This new project was structured and taught so thoughtfully, that I would consider it to be the main attraction for this course (which was already great to begin with), especially for newer developers who are sure to benefit greatly from seeing how all the individual concepts meld together into a simple but full-featured web app.

response.content: Dear Brian, thank you so much for taking your time and writing such a detailed review. I'm so excited to hear that my course has helped you gain better and deeper understanding of Angular and fill the missing gaps. Hope to see you again in my future courses. All the best!

results.content:
Mosh Hamedani is an exceptional technical teacher. He has years of experience, and not only knows the topic well, he also provides plenty of best practice tips, and multiple examples of how to solve problems... and gives reasons why one solution would be better than another.

My only problem with this course is that it is in need of an update now that Angular 6 is available, and some of the packages used in this course are outdated (primarily the section on Redux with ng2-redux - it needs to be updated for ngrx, although if you use your head you can relatively easily adapt your code to ngrx).

I am an experienced developer, so had no problems completing the course using Angular 5 - although to do this, some code needs to be modified to work, so perhaps less experienced developers may struggle in some parts.

Still, I would recommend any course by Mosh. His courses are super high quality - and even though the content of this course is in need of an update, the lessons in how to organise your projects etc are really valuable. He is without a doubt favourite teacher on any online training!

results.content:
This course is extremely outdated.  It is fine to learn the basics of Angular but, once you start building the practical application, the breaking changes become to difficult to overcome and is frustrating to follow.

Mainly, you'll have to make decisions about how to implement certain aspects of code along the way in order to get things functioning with the newest versions of Angular.  The issue is, if you are new to Angular, you may not know why certain things work in one situation but not another.  These type of decisions snowball into a collection of broken code.

If you are a beginner, I'd avoid this course.  If you are a seasoned developer and just wanting to learn Angular, it might be worth a go but I'm sure there are better options out there.
results.content_html:

results.content:
My rating has nothing to do with content being outdated because it is said it's angular 4, even though author is saying that not that much has changed, well it's not entirely true, because few sections from this course are thanks to that impossible to follow up in newer version, also after end of this course if You want to use newer version there is a lot to follow up on.

But my rating is not including that.

Through the course, there are some sections without coding challenges. In sections where they occur, they are on really beginning level (in reference to content that was in the section) so for me, it's missing some optional but more challenging tasks in the exercises (by that I mean covering everything that was discussed in the section).

He also shows how to write clean methods and how it should look like but he doesn't always follow the rules while writing code so by that he is teaching bad practices (there are sections with cleaning code at the end what was great, but not always he is refactoring code).

So that was the bad part, now good things!

If you have questions during the course, You will get an answer from the Teaching assistant, what is great. The teacher is speaking clearly and most of the times I understood everything that was taught.

results.content:
I really enjoyed the course.  Breaking the content up into manageable bites was very helpful.

Another thing that I (finally) started doing that might be useful to mention in the course was to do a commit after every lesson.  It made it much easier to roll back at times that I got to messing around with the code and may have broken a few things.  :)

For a course as in-depth as this, I would have liked some additional focus on "how" to find answers in the documentation for the resources used in the course and in the project.

That said, the course was wonderful!  And I very much appreciate it!

Scott

results.content:
5 star for the class, for the clarity, for the explanations, for the quality content. There were a lot of eyebrows raised with the previous material as the videos and the code was in 2 version and had to rely on the pdf which frustrated a lot of students. I guess, this course is indeed touching a lot of topics which i havent seen in other courses. Hoping to see the redux/ ngrx/ngRedux patterns & testing soon. As promised , he had delivered good quality materials for which we had to wait a bit! Keep the quality contents coming!.

[Update: 16-Aug ] : I just completed whatever content till the course had at this point of time, and i should say, mammoth effort from Mosh to come up with quality stuffs. I already feel confident to get my hands wet in depth. I had read his announcement of about 5+ hrs of content yet to come! Awwwesome!!!..keep it coming brother!.. The course is the best thing that happened to me for 10$ ever!

With this much content, the Q&A section will be flooded with a ton of queries, but unfortunately, i dont see it getting answered as often, thats the only sad part of this. But i guess thats the trade off we have to understand to let him focus on more quality content.

results.content:
I love Mosh's courses, and successfully launched a web-app for a local charity thanks to his MVC 5 course. Next month I'll be getting stuck into the real-world course on combining MVC, Angular et al to build a bigger course, and the old(er) Advanced C# course is my goto resource when I forget rarely used functionality, so the comments here are based out of both respect and a certain level of expectation.

1. This course will definitely teach you Angular, and give you insight into both good and bad practices with concise explanations.

2. It's a nightmare to follow along with. There is no (obvious) github repo in place, and code changes are made off-screen between videos. You are often left with no way to make something relatively simple work in the same way as the instructor without spending a lot of time taking guesses. After a few days, this became tiring and I resorted to just watching the videos... which lead to no real learning at all.

3. We can't expect courses to stay 100% up to date with changes, but Bootstrap 4 is now out, and if you follow the instructions in these videos you will install that version by default. With the removal of Glyphicons and a change to Panels in BS4, you're going to find some entire sections that won't work for you. Argh. This can really, really easily be resolved, and you can stick with BS3 for the purposes of taking this course. I'd recommend to Mosh that a simple text chapter be added right at the start of the course to help the many frustrated customers here. "Every time Mosh types npm install bootstrap --save into a terminal/console, replace it with npm install bootstrap@3 --save".

As I said, this is a great course, it's just annoying difficult to follow along and code every video yourself.

results.content: Although the stuff is a bit outdated, Angular is just another one of those frameworks that will change with time. What doesn't change as frequently is programming techniques and principles, which are taught very well throughout the course by Mosh. He gives good suggestions and tips for code reuse, maintainability and modularization.  All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed the course and will most likely recommend Mosh to someone else getting into Angular or programming in general.

All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed the course and will most likely recommend Mosh to someone else getting into Angular or programming in general.

results.content:
Mosh is a great teacher! I really enjoy to coding with him, the examples are really useful and I think the structure of the course is just great.

Unfortunately, this course was made with an older Angular version and there is a lot of out of date content, you need to spend a lot of time searching how to use some components in "now days" with the latest version. 
I don't think this is a reaaally hugh problem, but this does make you spent a lot of more time than it needed!

One good thing, there are a lot of students, so it's really common to see similar errors and they provide some solutions, anyway you have to search a lo of things to learn the latest version of angular.

results.content: I have taken all of Mosh's classes and he is by far, the best instructor that I've found on Udemy or other sites.  His material is very thoroughly researched and well developed, he maintains the content as things change (which is often the case with Angular), and he explains things in a simple, easily comprehendible way. results.content: I bought this course as an introduction to Angular, as I did not have any previous experience with it - and currently have a position that requires some knowledge on web development. Few weeks later I got surprised when my completion progress dropped to 45% although I had almost finished the course within a week or so. When I checked the reason, I could not believe! Mosh had doubled the course content and added a complete example to it. Seriously, with this course you can become a commercial web developer. For the price the course is usually listed, it is a must have. Mosh take code refactoring seriously as the code grows, and keep things organized. Although I prefer new commits to Github with the course section's development (as he did in other course about ASP.NET MVC), I understand some people prefer to download the code strips. My rating is 5 stars because I cannot add more.

results.content:
OK... It did start out really slow...20 videos into it and no Angular 4 material, but now that I am at video 134, I see that I am learning a lot and Mosh is covering every angle of Angular. I really have to say that this course is actually better than any PluralSight training I have taken. Mosh is a good instructor ( - even if he over-uses the word "Look" -) building on concepts he presented earlier. 

I like that you can download the lectures and the code examples, and code along with him, even though it takes (me) 5 times as long, I think it is definitely worth the effort if you want to master this language.

results.content:
Echt een hele goede cursus tot nu toe. Alle topics worden in theorie uitgelegd in met aanvullende contextinformatie. Daarnaast worden van verschillende methodes die je kunt gebruiken de voor en nadelen toegelicht. 

Als kers op de taart wordt bij alle theorie praktische voorbeelden gegeven.

In andere cursussen over angular heb ik ervaren dat of niet alle topics worden behandeld, de voorbeelden erg verwarrend worden en er weinig toelichting over de context wordt gegeven.

Voor mensen die angular willen leren raad ik deze cursus echt als topper aan. 

Overall:
-Inhoud is up to date
-Uitstekende uitleg van de individuele topics/de context
-Hele goede voorbeelden (niet verwarrend)

response.content:
Thanks Manfred for your review. 

Here's the translation in English: "A really good course so far. All topics are explained in theory with additional contextual information. In addition, various pros and cons that you can use explain the pros and cons. As a cherry on the cake, practical examples are given in theory. In other courses about angular, I have experienced that or not all topics are being treated, the examples are very confusing and little explanation about the context is given. For those who want to learn angular, I really recommend this course as a top teacher. Overall: - Content is up to date - Outstanding explanation of individual topics / context - Overall good examples (not confusing)"

results.content:
This course is very outdated. I spent more time trying to find suitable replacements than following along the course. Eventually, I just gave up because it was a hassle figuring out modern day solutions for Angular and Bootstrap. I understand software changes rapidly, but unfortunately this course is way behind the times.

If you like a challenge fixing all the compatibility issues, go ahead and purchase this course. Otherwise, your time is better spent elsewhere learning from a course that's more up to date.

results.content:
Hands down best course I’ve taken on Udemy. Mosh is an amazing instructor! You know he smiles while he is teaching you things just by hearing him speak. I truly feel a lot more comfortable with angular and know that if I’m lost, I don’t have to watch a 20 minute video to know how to do things right. Everything is clean and simply explained with minimal jargons.
Just a note though, if you are reading this. This course does not use the current version of angular (version 6). Therefore, a lot of the code he writes isn’t up to date. This means you’re going to have to see what you’re made of and solve problems (like a true programmer). But in the end, I think it’ll make you a better developer.

results.content:
Everything was going well with this course, until I hit the HTTP Services section. This section is probably the most important section because it covers one of the most important topics in Angular, working with REST APIs. The problem is that since Angular 4.3 and definitely Angular 5+, the @angular/http module was replaced with @angular/common/http, therefore making this section completely obsolete. The documentation for HTTPClient is not easy at all to follow and a tutorial is definitely needed here. 

Disappointing because I really enjoyed the course up until this point, but if I cannot understand how to work with REST APIs in a current version of Angular what is the point of learning Angular??? At this point, I am just frustrated and don't feel confident that I am learning the material well enough to work with the current LTS versions of Angular which are 8 and 9.

As of October 12, 2020, I cannot recommend this course, it's dated. I realize that Angular is a moving target, but Mosh, it's time to update your course, buddy, or take it down. I learned some things, but it's really disappointing to get 1/4th of the way through a course just to realize it's very dated. @angular/common/http has been a thing since March 23, 2017 roughly.

results.content:
Many critical subjects, such as firebase, are out dated. Many concept just doesn't apply anymore. For a beginner like me is extremely confused. Many examples in the video just does not function the same with the current version of library. Though there are user provide some solutions, not all of them give clear reason why is the things written the way they are, cost extra time to get through the course

the later the course, the worst it gets. spend most of the time trying figure out why example doesn't work. While it is also a way of leaning, its wasting too much unexpended time required to go through the course. And for me, I feel more confused with Angular especially after going through the project example...

=========
more update:

Also the TA is NOT really helpful. Its good that Udemy has TA for the course, but I feel they didn't really watch through the course, so when students ask the question they cannot empathize and understand the questions. Often I got some solution from the peers instead. And, sometimes there are "fixes" in the later lecture, but the TA seems unaware and not be able to help the students efficiently.

results.content:
I'm actually on the fifth section.

It's a really great training. I have already a little background on Angular, so it's actually easy for me and I take some little trick from time to time.

Just a half star removed due to some changes done on some API and that are not reflected on the video (But I know it's a huge work to update it).

For instance, angular material component prefix are now 'mat' and not 'md'. But with some research on the angular material website, it's possible to continue learning.

Save yourself the time and find an updated with better assistants who are actually interested in helping.

results.content:
Course is Superb, Mosh provides everything that we need.
Short supercool videos, CODE along with it - you will learn more!!
While coding along you will think of new ideas that you can incorporate and will look for answers which will increase your knowledge.
We can see lot of HardWork from Mosh in these lectures.

If you are using Angular 5 then keep a note of two things - 
1) Angular Http Services section have new HttpClient Module where we don't need the map operator to convert to JSON.
2) New Angular Material requires 'Mat' syntax instead of 'Md'. Eg - Use MatButtonModule instead of MdButtonModule.

This might be helpful if anyone is looking for this info.
Mosh will update this also I guess in his lectures.

If you have read my review and you are thinking whether I should take it or not - 'I will say Loudly - Please Take It'.
Thanks Mosh you are excellent tutor. Keep up the good work :-)

results.content: Mosh is positive, energetic, clear, and to the point. He uses helpful analogies and practical examples to convey difficult concepts. He also does a good job of layering on complexity over time rather than all at once. Some of the concepts moved somewhat quickly for me, and some of the content is no longer accurate for the latest versions of Angular, but a little bit of resourcefulness helped me to make it work. Overall, solid course.

results.content:
After about 12 months I had to edit and change my initial 5-star review. I still think that Mosh is a good teacher but I had to pause the course after a couple basic lectures because I wasn't able to follow the examples. I was an absolute beginner and some concepts were too complex or maybe assumed some prior knowledge. 

I then purchased another course (by Max) and followed it from start to end. I was hoping to try to learn these basic concepts and then continue with Mosh's course. It took a long while because I wanted to be thorough and had to do this after hours but after completing the Max's Angular course, I decided to give this one another try and finish it. 

Unfortunately a lot has change over the past 12 months and, as noticed by many people who review this, Mosh's instructions are mostly outdated. I admit that I am way more proficient in Angular then when I first started Mosh's course so I am capable of overcoming these inconsistencies but as a beginner you might struggle, especially if you have to consult documentation about angular/rxjs, which doesn't work as described in these lectures.

The point is that this is no longer suitable for people who want to learn Angular 8 or 9, 10. This will leave you frustrated because you won't be able to complete any of the tasks properly if you don't know what changed and what to look out for since this was released. 

To put things in perspective, let me just add that the other instructor (Maximilian) updates his course on a regular basis and ever re-shoots lectures about concepts that are no longer up to date. Since Max got 5 stars from me, I cannot possibly give this course more than two stars, and I must say, two stars is very generous, all things considered.

To give credit where credit is due, I am very satisfied with Mosh's examples and ideas for projects. They are very practical and make sense to me. I might change this review once I receive info that this course has been updated. 

Overall, don't waste your money on this one. Hopefully Mosh can update this because he is a great teacher.
results.content_html:
After about 12 months I had to edit and change my initial 5-star review. I still think that Mosh is a good teacher but I had to pause the course after a couple basic lectures because I wasn't able to follow the examples. I was an absolute beginner and some concepts were too complex or maybe assumed some prior knowledge.

I then purchased another course (by Max) and followed it from start to end. I was hoping to try to learn these basic concepts and then continue with Mosh's course. It took a long while because I wanted to be thorough and had to do this after hours but after completing the Max's Angular course, I decided to give this one another try and finish it.

Unfortunately a lot has change over the past 12 months and, as noticed by many people who review this, Mosh's instructions are mostly outdated. I admit that I am way more proficient in Angular then when I first started Mosh's course so I am capable of overcoming these inconsistencies but as a beginner you might struggle, especially if you have to consult documentation about angular/rxjs, which doesn't work as described in these lectures.

The point is that this is no longer suitable for people who want to learn Angular 8 or 9, 10. This will leave you frustrated because you won't be able to complete any of the tasks properly if you don't know what changed and what to look out for since this was released.

To put things in perspective, let me just add that the other instructor (Maximilian) updates his course on a regular basis and ever re-shoots lectures about concepts that are no longer up to date. Since Max got 5 stars from me, I cannot possibly give this course more than two stars, and I must say, two stars is very generous, all things considered.

To give credit where credit is due, I am very satisfied with Mosh's examples and ideas for projects. They are very practical and make sense to me. I might change this review once I receive info that this course has been updated.

Overall, don't waste your money on this one. Hopefully Mosh can update this because he is a great teacher.

results.content:
Not recommended for those who are starting out and wish to quickly learn. The basics of angular can be learned in 8 hours. This course goes into excruciating detail about angular that is not expected of a beginner. Some modules are out dated. 

Recommended only for users who wish to deepen their knowledge. It also has a good practice project. However the author himself breaks the project code a lot within the training video. This will leave students confused as to what just happened.

Mosh needs to understand that we are not trying to learn refactoring techniques here. We are learning angular. Mosh, please do not implement stuff then show us how to do it better. Show the better way  immediately. This teaching method of yours keeps breaking the project and that is not helpful at all.
results.content_html:

Mosh needs to understand that we are not trying to learn refactoring techniques here. We are learning angular. Mosh, please do not implement stuff then show us how to do it better. Show the better way immediately. This teaching method of yours keeps breaking the project and that is not helpful at all.

results.content: I basically changed my opinion about this course. There is another great, and fairly up-to-date project that is still actively supported by the actual author and very able support staff. Mosh hasn't updated critical parts of the course and hasn't responded to many questions, leaving the students to fend for themselves. Also, there are some grating errors in this tutorial that make me nigh furious. It was an 'Okay' course to get started, but the more I learned the more flawed it appeared to be.

results.content:
Het is een mooie, uitgebreide cursus met veel oefeningen die ook in echte enterprise applications van toepassing zijn. Het is een heel duidelijke, gestructureerde uitleg. Hij beschrijft ook heel duidelijk hoe alles werkt.
Er kon enkel wat minder focus gelegd worden op het leren van API's zoals de animations en firebase.
Dit zijn slechts API's, die je niet altijd gebruikt en die je indien nodig op dat moment wel aanleert.
Verder ben ik heel tevreden over de cursus. De theorie samen met de goeie oefeningen zorgen er voor dat je de materie goed begrijpt.
Er werd ook heel veel gecovered in de cursus.

results.content:
The course is excellent.  The instructor is a great communicator, provides lots of visuals, and keeps each video short and to the point.

The final project is very thorough, demonstrating best practices and how to properly structure a project; this helped cement the knowledge learned throughout the course.  Angular has a fairly steep learning curve and working through the project enabled me to get the most from my investment.  

I would definitely purchase more courses from Mosh.

results.content: I keep on lagging on taking the course and forget both where I was last and what was done so far. But this is my own fault as I need to keep up with doing the course more so it happens less. Overall, the course is very straight forward and I look forward to getting into the more advanced uses as I just got to Property Binding but I'm an experienced programmer and have been in IT for the past 15 yrs so everything to this point has been very "hello world" level basic for me. I even built my application with all of the components and services from the course thus far in one project and thus both my "courses" component and my "authors" component appear on the same page... still isn't anything complex compared to the applications I've been involved with developing and/or supporting but for learning purposes it has helped to make it a little more challenging for me. Bring on the harder stuff!

results.content: For me, Mosh's style of teaching is perfect. He presents with succinct clarity, explains what needs to happen and then asks "How do we do this?" After showing how, he explains why. His objective is to simplify not complicate. I love his calling "injection dependencies" a "$25 term with a 5¢ meaning." He made understanding this possible. Showing how and explaining why in response to a question is for me what the best instructors do. So far, this is a six-star course in a five-star rating system. Thanks Mosh!

results.content: Mosh is a fantastic tutor, and has done a tremendous work! The lectures are great and enlightening and the pace fantastic! However, the course is now outdated and has not been revised for the latest Angular version. Besides other problems here and there (especially with obsolete libraries), the project - which is the core of the course - cannot be completed due to major updates both in Firebase and in Angular as well. As a beginner, I've struggled for hours within the documentation, trynig to update the obsolete code bit by bit and with every problem I solved, I was encountering a new one. Finally I came to a dead end and the project was left unfinished and at an early stage, really a shame.
results.content_html: Mosh is a fantastic tutor, and has done a tremendous work! The lectures are great and enlightening and the pace fantastic! However, the course is now outdated and has not been revised for the latest Angular version. Besides other problems here and there (especially with obsolete libraries), the project - which is the core of the course - cannot be completed due to major updates both in Firebase and in Angular as well. As a beginner, I've struggled for hours within the documentation, trynig to update the obsolete code bit by bit and with every problem I solved, I was encountering a new one. results.content:
This course was good in terms of delivering content but terrible otherwise. The most important problem with it is that it was recorded on angular 2, we're at angular 9 now and most of http services, firebase, redux and many other features work completely differently. I had most of the time to find the solution for myself, which is kinda good in a way that i was forced to work by myself but very frustrating otherwise. Also Mosh is the kind of developer who tends to self indulge a bit too much with refactoring. Why would you make me do something one way, and then make me scrap it completely to refactor it? Why won't you tell people to do things the right way in the first place?
I'm definitely going to avoid any other course from Mosh in the future.

results.content:
Before taking this course I had a little JavaScript experience and no experience of JS frameworks or TypeScript. I frankly find the whole JS and front end development world very confusing and not knowing where to start. After deciding to get my feet wet in Angular I decided to take this course and this course has been really amazing.

The course itself is really well broken down and digestible, the instructor’s explanations and presentation of the material is amazing and the tasks at the end of each section are very enjoyable and rewarding to complete. My only qualm is that after completing the challenge I wanted to a few more to really solidify the concepts taught but nevertheless this doesn’t take away from the quality of the course and material.

The one thing that I have always found in Mosh Hamedani’s courses is that he always gives you the best practices and principles so you are not only learning a concept but the best way to apply it and that is priceless as that is what you would get sitting next to a seasoned developer.

I give this course a 5 star rating for the depth of material, comprehensiveness, presentation and quality as well as being really enjoyable and fun to go through. 

Thank you Mosh.

results.content: There is a lot of useful stuff here, but the lessons keep jumping back and forth between code examples, so you often find yourself having to retype the content of the files as they were several lessons ago because in between there's been other lessons using completely different code in the same files. The instructor also does not leave much time to catch up with writing code, so there is a lot of pausing the videos. The worst part however, is that the instructor repeatedly changes things around in ways that breaks the functionality he's just shown, especially when showing different ways to do something he's just covered. The new ways will not work as shown, because the rest of the code that makes it work is being removed. This is tied to the problem of the entire course seemingly revolving around editing the same files over and over again replacing their content entirely multiple times, which really makes it difficult to keep up, especially for the more complex topics. I would prefer to have new files created for covering new topics instead, so that you can actually go back and look at what has been done when recapping for my own sake.

results.content:
It's ok...The course is fairly outdated by today's standards like it's taught on Angular 4.  It's 2020 the Angular version out these days is Angular 10.  A lot of the Q&A is students asking why something is not working which is also somewhat good because you have to go out of your way to find the information yourself and student do usually help each other which is a good thing to see as the students are all quite helpful towards each other.

The teaching assistance is a bit condescending towards students as well and is not very active I see some posts with no reply from 6 months ago and some posts from a month ago telling them to find the answer on another post.  I also saw a student say when the course will be updated to Angular 10 and the TA said basically to the student "That they can go create their own course" don't know why they're a teaching assistant if they don't want to help? 

Overall, maybe in 2016/2017, this would have been the go-to Angular course on Udemy but by today's standards, there are much better courses out there.  I am pretty disappointed by this course 2/5

results.content: This was an excellent course... 2-3 years ago. Now it is still good with all the detailed and clear explanations (Mosh is really good at it). But the material is terribly outdated now. It was a real challenge for me to code along and figure out all the differences between 2016 and 2020 versions of angular and the dependencies utilized in this course. At times it got really frustrating (I gave up on creating a fake back end in the "Authentication" chapter and went for a different solution). But also one could argue that having to do a lot of own research might have helped with the learning process.

results.content:
First of all Thanks to Mosh to deliver us such a excellent course. This course is too good for beginner. I am started from zero and now perfect in Angular after completion.
 
But frankly speaking, The course looks outdated once i started project. 
I never face any major issue during core section of courses. But after started project work I personally fill that there are lots of changes happen in Angular-6, fire base and angular-fire-2, which is very much confusing for a beginner. I have faced some major issue which took more than a day to resolve. As a service man If you learn this and get this type of issues, you need serious dedication to get out of this.

So I  suggest to update course with latest angular with latest fire-base version and deliver what all changes happen if someone use latest version.

Though I told that this course is outdated, but I personally believes that is someone will give 200% effort and fully dedicated to learn angular 2 or higher, this is the perfect course. No Matter of what version delivered here. In Front-End world everyday some new update will come. So if anyone want to learn angular means he/ she should prepare to handle this kind of updates.
If you really want to learn Angular then try to code your own, take reference of Mosh' videos  but don't just download and run it. I used all latest version and completed this course after lots of hard work.
Always I took his videos as reference during coding, never negotiate with my latest version. I I faced some issue, then search in google or ask a question. Some time they helps, sometime I found answer, some of those  are time consuming but I never hands up. And today i gain a level of confidence that i can also deploy angular application.

results.content: I've taken many courses from Mosh and I'm rather disappointed in this one.  The material it out of date and in many cases he uses version 3 of bootstrap for icons but this version won't install anymore and the icons are no longer available in version 4.  I also don't care for the exercises, would be nice to have some more guidance such as whether property binding should be used in the exercise etc.  I am now on section 7 of the course and I've tried to use another library to replace Bootstrap so I can get the icons to show but haven't been able to get it to work.  I asked in the Q & A and got a completely useless answer from the TA, was told to search the questions but there really isn't a good example of how to implement a different library like Font Awesome.  I've always been quite happy with the detail and content in Mosh's courses but now that this course is older, he's really dropped the ball,  don't know what it will be like to do the project if you can't even get the icons to work.  If you're looking for an Angular course, probably best to bypass this one and look for a more current course where the instructor updates it regularly.
results.content_html: I've taken many courses from Mosh and I'm rather disappointed in this one. The material it out of date and in many cases he uses version 3 of bootstrap for icons but this version won't install anymore and the icons are no longer available in version 4. I also don't care for the exercises, would be nice to have some more guidance such as whether property binding should be used in the exercise etc. I am now on section 7 of the course and I've tried to use another library to replace Bootstrap so I can get the icons to show but haven't been able to get it to work. I asked in the Q & A and got a completely useless answer from the TA, was told to search the questions but there really isn't a good example of how to implement a different library like Font Awesome. I've always been quite happy with the detail and content in Mosh's courses but now that this course is older, he's really dropped the ball, don't know what it will be like to do the project if you can't even get the icons to work. If you're looking for an Angular course, probably best to bypass this one and look for a more current course where the instructor updates it regularly.

results.content:
The course is Perfect! it is one of the most detailed Angular courses across all of the online learning platforms but...

It is pretty outdated! I had to stop at the Http requests module since it's demonstrated using a deprecated package, I went out and looked up the current package and found it, but kept running into issues that I had to figure out myself. As fun and educating as this can be, I had no time to keep doing it specially that I'm going through this course with a project waiting for me to finish. 
I am going through this bit from another tutorial, and I may come back to continue from here again (provided that there is no more hurdles in the future).
So again.. the course is fine, one of the best, except for the fact that it is more than 2 years old as of the time of writing this comment, so expect that you might finish the course to find stuff a bit different out there.

I have to say a big congratulations to Mosh for the quality of his course.
Mosh is a great teacher, he knows how to use simple words to explain complicated things. I am a French developer and my English is very average, but I understood all its explanations.
This is a very well structured course with simple but effective examples and I think this is the best Angular course I have found.
I also followed other Mosh's courses like AspNet Core and Angular which is also very well done.

The instructor is good and engaging but the course structure is somewhat messy in places.

The main problems are practical exercises which are incomplete/do not work without fixing them manually (not acceptable for a course suitable for beginners) and the total lack of engagement on the Q&A section from the instructor or anyone involved in the production of the course. Of course it's good for students to help each other but there is no response when people highlight issues with the course itself.

Very good course. Great teacher!
Very simple and understandable explanations. The course goes into detail, explains everything very precisely, but neither too long nor too short.
You learn a lot about Typscript, some about HTML and DOM and of course about Angular.
Some methods and modules used in this course are out of date, but it is no problem, because the principles are still valid.
I don't understand the bad votes because of this, because with the given principles it is easy to adapt it for the updated methods and modules, at least if you are not an absouletely beginner who is only copying code without using the brain.

results.content:
The lessons that give an overview of Angular, which make up the bulk of the course, are a good resource and a great reference point to be able to refer back to.

Once you get onto the projects though it's largely outdated.  That is the nature of the beast, but it would have been good to be warned about that up front.

If you just want a handy resource on Angular then this course is good, but if you want something that will show you practical applications of it I wouldn't recommend it.
results.content_html:
The lessons that give an overview of Angular, which make up the bulk of the course, are a good resource and a great reference point to be able to refer back to.

results.content: I want to say that I have purchased several of Mosh's courses and EVERY one is fantastic.  This one is as well.  Why three stars?  Because he has decided not to keep it up to date with the changes in newer versions of Angular.  Had he done so or had he done a new updated course I'm sure I would highly recommend.  I got about a third of the way through this course and ran into the second occurrence of something he shows that no longer works.  I had to stop and buy the one by Maximilian Schwarzmüller that is so highly rated.  So far I'm liking his as well.

results.content:
Perfect course on Angular. I came into this as a c# developer who has done a couple of Mosh's other courses in c#.

I've been trying to get into web for a while, in particular Angular, but it always seemed pretty daunting. Mosh walks you through each part in good detail, covering everything slowly, and showing you some of the pitfalls along the way. Add to that, the fact that it's only about 8 hours total really helps you stay focused on the goal at hand.

Highly recommended!

results.content:
This is the best angular course available online. The course take you gradually through the basics of typescript and angular and finally present a practical Ecommerce Web App all made in Angular. There is also advance sections on reactive forms, material design, animation, Http service etc. 

Mosh has very nicely laid the course structure so that you dont have any problem when you finally start working on the provided project demo. The course has several concepts bundled in; which make anyone adept with practical angular and that too very quicky. Moreover, the course is loaded with several tips essential to work efficiently in a real world. The course is itself presented excellently which make everything very easy and intuitive even for a novice. 

Thanks Mosh for putting up such a nice course. Thanks to your course I am finally able to develop my long time dream web projects without any hassle.

results.content:
The course was very comprehensive. I appreciate the fact that when Mosh would encounter numerous ways for developing a solution, he'd identify the options, when you would use each option, and the reasoning for his choices.  I also appreciate it when he would encounter errors and provide explanation on how to resolve them. Often times trainers try to provide the "perfect" course (omitting errors) which is to the detriment of the student. Programming promises errors, and part of learning is knowing how to go about solving them. 

The course got a little too fast at the start of the "projects" section where I felt like I was typing and not completely understanding, but I think this is assuming students have completely mastered the prior material. If you stick through these areas (sometimes rewinding, and even stop to do other outside research) the learning is manageable and I was able to keep up in the end. Thanks Mosh for a great lesson. It's evident you put a lot of effort in considering the needs of your students. Blessings to you and your future success.

results.content:
Excellent course at the perfect pace with an excellent outline of building on concepts from basic to advanced.  Great explanations of why - not just the syntax - and very good best practices thrown in.  And of course, Mosh is a great and experienced presenter - very enjoyable to listen to as in instructor!

One suggestion to make this course even better - please provide a page or link that lists by course section / lecture where the example presented breaks with current versions of code and any hints / links to how to fix (can even let the users of the course help to identify breakage / provide links and fixes.  It's frustrating when you are trying to learn and can't get something to work as instructed and learn that it is a code version issue - not something you are doing wrong.  But this too is a learning experience!

results.content: Mosh as usual is the best teacher. Those who are criticizing him should know that some of his courses were misused by people and uploaded on YouTube, he called out to them to remove those copyright content as it is his original work and he put his efforts to create course for us but nothing happened and perhaps that's the reason he is no longer available on Udemy or left it for good. He has his own websites now "programmingwithmosh.com" and "codewithmosh.com". Also, check some of his crash courses he put on YouTube freely for python, java etc. You will be amazed the way he teaches and make you understand the harder concept so easily. Though this course might have been very famous during the days of its inception however, at current date it needs serious update or written notes wherever required. I learnt a lot from Mosh over the period of time. And I also agree with everyone out there that this course need a serious update.

results.content: I personally liked the angular course. It gave me sufficient knowledge which I was looking for being a back-end developer with no experience in front end technologies. Knowledge communication through examples and a small exercise after every topic were the key things which made the learning smooth. On what can be improved, I would want the courses to be updated with the new Angular version changes. As the course was build on older version of angular, certain libraries/dependencies are no more available with the new version, we have to look for an alternative for those dependencies. Having said this the changes from old to new version weren't huge but it will be of a benefit. Overall pretty good. :)

results.content:
Mosh did a good job explaining the ins and outs of Angular and Typescript. It was the first Angular course I have taken and I am fairly satisfied with the outcome. I liked it so much, I bought a second course by Mosh. It is 'modern' as of October 2017 and I say this because I had no issues with versions, etc. 

Something to improve: Get to the point. Sometimes Mosh explains 4 ways to do one thing, and at the end I just care about the best way. If there are scenarios where doing it a different way is better, then show us that scenario. 

Idea/suggestion for a new course: There is a rails course called 8 Beautiful Rails Apps. I liked that one because it gives you 8 versions of doing things slightly different, which gets the brain working on the different things you can do. Maybe Mosh can do one like that for Angular :)

results.content:
I am taking 3rd Angular course in Udemy so I can compare.
It is not the best Angular course in Udemy:
1) Examples of code are not attached to many lectures, so if you missed anything, it could be hard to repair your code
2) The main disadvantage is that it is really outdated and there is no info how to update the code so that it works again. I.e. if you write the code as on video, it will not work in new Angular 7, rxjs, but there is no explanation even in Q&A how to fix, it is time wasting. Help staff doesn't answer properly.
3) Some exercises are missing for many months and there is no info on them, i.e. Unit Test assignment - people asking for many months to add it because no ZIP file attached but still no such file.
In general, I would recommend Maximilian Schwarzmüller because at least he updates on how to fix the code for Angular 7 everywhere and help staff really helps answering questions very fast, code examples are always attached.

results.content: Mosh is a great teacher.  I've taken 5 or 6 classes on Udemy and he is by far the best instructor I've come across.  What makes him so great is that he explains what you do AND WHY you do it, gives examples of other options and why they are not your best solution.  He also defines terms that are specific to the subject and terms the student might not be familiar with.  Mosh's coverage of the material is also very comprehensive.  For example, he covers usage of the built-in directives and shows you how to build custom directives.

results.content: This is a high quality course. Mosh has designed the course in an efficient way. What I really commend him for is his tone: I never felt overwhelmed with new material, but I also I never felt like he over-simplified either. Perfect balance! In fact, among the courses to learn Angular, as soon as I saw Mosh as an instructor, I knew this was the right course for me. I am an iOS developer learning web technologies for the first time, although I have taken other courses from Mosh. I recommend this course to anyone following that route.

results.content:
A lot of technology updates and misfires have made it extremely challenging to sustain momentum. Not sure I'm absorbing much at this point tbh.

It gets even worse in Section 9. The whole thing is outdated and I spent far more time hunting down half-baked solutions than actually learning anything. Without many code files to compare my own to, I have no idea what works and what doesn't. Very discouraging and completely unlearnable.

Quitting the course to pursue one more updated. Not terribly beginner friendly.

results.content:
I like the course not just because Mosh explains the concepts very well, but also he taught me some JS stuff that I didn't know that exists (eg. Shadow DOM). Moreover, he filled up some of my gaps (eg. JWT explained; showed me the difference between the HTTP methods).

Actually, I liked the course because he always showed me what's under the hood. For example, he teach me how can I do things manually without the async pipe. 

He also made me to understand the fundamental concepts of programming, get rid of spaghetti code by underlying the importance of separation of concerns and also avoiding memory leaks.

Is worth mentioning that he also teached me some technical details (eg. AOT, JIT), but the most important thing is that he build from scratch a real world application and deployed it.

Sure, I would have liked to have taught me more about directives and few other stuff, but to be honest, if you go through this tutorial, you can easily learn about this stuff on your own. Also, along the course I got some errors because of Angular 6, but this helped me to understand what was going on.

Sure, I would have liked to have taught me more about directives and few other stuff, but to be honest, if you go through this tutorial, you can easily learn about this stuff on your own. Also, along the course I got some errors because of Angular 6, but this helped me to understand what was going on.

results.content:
This course is awesome and teaches you a lot of things in depth. Mosh provides a lot of tips to help remember and understand things, and is also great for learning how to code properly (refactoring, separation of concerns, etc...). I would give the content of this course a 5/5 rating.

The thing that really takes away from the quality of this course is that naturally you will have a lot of questions. And the nature of programming is that it's continuously evolving so certain features won't work as they previously did. Fair enough. The issue I have is that the TA for this course is not very helpful. It doesn't seem like he cares or doesn't take the time to answer questions properly. A lot of students are left confused with certain sections because the TA cannot resolve the issues, or doesn't give proper responses. With code that is outdated, he doesn't help students understand how things have changed.
results.content_html:

results.content:
Pros:-
-Highlights the concepts before going to implementation.
-Step by step development with continuous refactoring to target clean code showing best practices.
-Detail-oriented 
-His ideas and concepts are organised and clear which making it easy to follow.

Cons:-
-Lack of some advanced topics such as (Component Interaction -State Management - Security - Observable).
-Project is so depending on Firebase instead of http endpoints.
-Based on author speaking high about the project it was overrated 
- Excessive usage of beta and versions of libraries.
-First sections don't have source code before and after the examples.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I'm an experience developer, and have learned lots of TIPS and TRICKS that I was not aware off.  This is an extensive course with plenty of information to learn from. Mosh walks your through creating a full working shopping cart.  Putting all the knowledge learned from the course into a full working app. Great for any new or exiscting Angular developer that wants to creat a full working App.

Note: If you are using angular 8+, ngrx and firebase imports are a little different. You will need to look at the Docs as things have changed.
